Award.AwardTitle: CHS: Small: The Future of Geospatial Data: The Analytics and Implications of Open Source Mapping

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will produce methods and tools in the critical area of geospatial data that both the larger computer science research community can use as well as the public-sector and private-sector development communities. Geospatial data are a critical area of research and development, notably in supporting rapid response to disasters arising from natural or technological hazards, as well as other sudden crises. This research will deeply investigate the conditions under which volunteer-generated data in "open source mapping" environments are generated and used. The tools developed in this project will help further validate volunteer-generated open geospatial data, and enable appropriate use through better analytical inspection methods. In addition, the connections between social computing activities and impacts on the world will be substantiated in clear ways, especially through the windows of humanitarian events and societal resilience-building. How open mapping can be made more viable for social problems will also be advanced through this research.

To achieve these goals, the team will design, develop, deploy, and evaluate a software infrastructure and its associated application programming interface that operates on large historical files of OpenStreetMap data. OpenStreetMap is a 2+ million member, decade-old volunteer-based organization that has created a "open data" based digital map of the world. This research will allow examination of the interpersonal, group, and organizational means by which collaborative cartography is accomplished through social computing. It will then examine the implications of having open geospatial data available to humanitarian efforts, which are important drivers to socio-technical change, including that of disaster response, resilience-building of critical infrastructure, and other governmental responsibilities. The research combines computational and behavioral analytics to address critical questions at multiple levels of analysis, from database instantiation to institutional use.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this project is to understand both quantitatively and qualitatively the conditions under which volunteer-generated data in ?open source mapping? environments are generated and used.

We focus in particular on OpenStreetMap (OSM), the "wikipedia of maps," that has been around for nearly two decades and today is approaching 7M members. We are interested in how users collaborate to generate, validate, and share geospatial data, and then use that data for community-to-government engagement. Our team has also designed, developed, deployed, and evaluated software tools that operate on OpenStreetMap data to study the interpersonal, group, and organizational means by which collaborative cartography is accomplished through social computing. Corporate involvement in geospatial data generation has since emerged as another important factor in OSM work, and became an aspect of the project?s analysis. Our research examined the implications of having open geospatial data available to humanitarian efforts which are important drivers for socio-technical change, including that of disaster response, resilience-building of critical infrastructure, and other governmental responsibilities.

Over the entirety of the project, our research and development work has contributed in multiple  methodological and technological ways, and has uncovered key phenomena about the OSM open data initiative. Methodologically, the research has demonstrated advanced ways of visually depicting geospatial data that created new ways to investigate the composition and work product of the global effort. This work resulted in multiple tools and services that are freely available via github: github.com/Project-EPIC. We have published multiple scientific articles and blog posts that document and make these tools and services publicly available. Results of these methodological and technological capacities have revealed how collaboration in OpenStreetMap happens and how it is organized over time and space. We have described how new contributors gain expertise, and how geospatial data is being commercialized via hybrid forms of authorship that combine both volunteer and corporate interests.

Over the past year, our research has become recognized as the authoritative source of information on the growing involvement of large corporations in the OpenStreetMap project and how their involvement has impacted the stated mission of OpenStreetMap. These companies include Apple, Facebook, Amazon, Microsoft, and others who are both using the data in their products and employing teams of contributors to edit the map at increasingly larger scales. Our research continues to monitor this growing phenomenon and quantify the impact that the involvement of these corporations has on the map across various regions of the globe.

The study of this new complicating turn in OpenStreetMap?s history continues to require the development of global-scale analysis-specific datasets that we generate monthly using the NSF-funded ChameleonCloud cloud-computing platform. These datasets are made publicly available (LINK) and we continue to collaborate with others in the larger OSM community to answer questions about the growth of this online community of globally distributed volunteer mappers. We have also collaborated with the Heidelberg Institute for GeoInformation Technology (HeiGIT) to develop and release the first iteration of OSM-Interactions, a sharable dataset of OpenStreetMap editing history that enables researchers to conduct global-scale analysis of OpenStreetMap. This dataset is here: github.com/jenningsanderson/osm-interactions/.
